div.bibl: Lietuva, Dec. 31, 1909.CAN WE BE PROUD OF LITHUANIAN EMIGRATION? by J. Laukis

body.p:
Lithuanian immigrants in the United States' are now commemorating the fortieth anniversary of Lithuanian mass emigration to America. I will not say that this move is entirely a bad thing, especially since the proceeds from these commemorative affairs, which are being held in all principal Lithuanian-American colonies, go towards a fund for the publication of instruction books for our schools; that is a very worthy cause. However, it is very unbecoming to conduct such affairs for the purpose of boasting of our emigration. It is unbecoming, because after we abandoned our homes in the Fatherland, where we could have continued to live in peace, we came to America and did not find a better life. When we came to America, we found that the only way we could make a living was by accepting the hardest and filthiest jobs, which are fraught with all kinds of dangers to our health and lives. Of what value are the larger earnings if the jobs sap the vitality from our bodies too early, rob
us of our health, embitter our lives, and send us to an untimely grave?

Mr. Joseph Gabrys (world-famous Lithuanian leader and patriot)
recently stated in the Lietuva (Lithuania) that it would not be possible to definitely ascertain whether or not Lithuanian emigration to America has been beneficial until after a statistical
survey of the Lithuanians in America has been made. However, the miserable plight
of our people, and the harmful effects of emigration to America are so clearly
visible that no statistical survey is necessary in order to see them.

First: Emigration to America is detrimental to us--the immigrants. The high wages, of which we boast so much, do not last long; after a period of good times, years of depression come, and we are forced to spend everything we earned during the good times. We boast of American luxuries, but such products as Swift's artificially cured ham and the best American beer adversely affect our health; we have no reason to boast about them. Second: The wealth which we possess, both personal and real, such as the churches we built, do not belong to us. It could
have been acquired without coming to America, if we would have exerted as much labor and energy in Lithuania as we do here in America. Third: We have also failed to rise in the intellectual field above our brothers in the Fatherland. Morally, we appear to
be lower than our people in Lithuania.

Therefore, after taking everything into consideration, we find that
we did not gain anything by coming to America. Not only did we fail to gain anything here, but our emigration has harmed our Fatherland; our emigration has
decreased the number of workers, without which no country can rise culturally.
America boasts of her industrial greatness, but that greatness is entirely due to
the large and incessant flow of emigrants from foreign lands. The social and
economic status of Americans in the Southern states, where practically no immigrants settle, is just as miserable as that of our people in Lithuania.

Our Fatherland does not enjoy any immigration. On the contrary, our countrymen
in Lithuania are abandoning everything, and fleeing to foreign lands; some are
forced to go, but the greater majority leave on their own accord.
The result is, as should be expected, an intensification of the
miserable conditions which exist in our Fatherland. The social,
economic, and cultural uplift of any country depends upon the
inhabitants. A country which has a shortage of inhabitants cannot
expect to enjoy any appreciable degree of prosperity. Our countrymen evidently, are not aware of this important fact. As a result,
they are trying to find a more abundant life by fleeing to the wastes of Siberia,
or to some other land. The greater majority are coming to America, where they
expect to find mountains of gold. They are showing no concern over the fact that
when they leave their Fatherland they increase the hardships of their countrymen
which they leave behind. And, as if to laugh at our brothers who remain in the
Fatherland, we are celebrating an anniversary of our emigration with the apparent
conviction that it is something of which we ought to be proud. That is our great
sin, although we my not realize it.

However, not all Lithuanians are blind to the folly of celebrating our emigration
anniversary; there are souls who see it very clearly, and consequently look upon
it with discouragement. The other day I happened to hear the
reading of a letter from a prisoner, who is serving a four year
sentence in Russia for his activities in behalf of the Fatherland
(Lithuania). The letter, which consists of eight pages in minute
handwriting, was sent to a friend in America. It is filled with
convincing arguments about the dire consequences of Lithuanian
emigration. "Go, speak, and open the eyes of Lithuanian newspapermen to this evil; let them explain to the people how detrimental emigration
is to our Fatherland," pleads a distressing voice from behind the walls of a
Russian prison to us Lithuanian-Americans, who are quietly suffering in the land
of liberty.

Perhaps we will wake up some day and recognize the evil consequences of emigration from our Fatherland. But while we sleep, others are preparing to take
advantage of our indifferent attitude in regard to this matter. The large Polish
landowners in Lithuania are no longer able to reap a profit from their lands because of the growing shortage of cheap labor. As a result, they are being forced
to abandon their land. But they have decided to take advantage of this bad
situation by performing a patriotic deed for their nationality.
They are dividing their large land holdings into small parcels,
and are inviting Poles to emigrate to Lithuania and purchase
these parcels of land at bargain prices. Since the land is very
fertile, it affords an excellent opportunity for a comfortable
livelihood.

It is not strange that foreigners are able to find opportunities for making a
comfortable living in the very same land from which we are fleeing for fear of
a famine? Therefore, we cannot blame conditions in our Fatherland if we were
unable to make a living there. Instead, we should blame ourselves for not knowing how to live. There cannot be any doubt that foreigners will live and become prosperous on the land which we have abandoned, unless we hurry and reclaim
it. The foreigners will work hard, develop trading possibilities, raise their
standards of culture, and all that will be left for us to do will be to envy them.
The marvelous deeds which the foreigners will perform in our Fatherland will not
serve to warm our hearts. The cultural and commercial progress they make will be
foreign to our people; and, eventually, they will turn our native land into a
foreign land; we will become foreigners in our own Fatherland.
The full significance of all this is known to everyone who has
gone to a foreign country to look for bread. It is possible to
find wealth and happiness in a foreign country, but neither
wealth nor happiness in a foreign country can obliterate the
fond memories of our native land, the ties of consanguinity, and
the congenial social atmosphere--these precious memories will
remain with us as long as we live. That is the direction in which we are headed
--the loss of our Fatherland to foreigners.

Mr. Dumbre, a popular Lithuanian writer and patriot, recently wrote an article
on the above subject. The article is entitled "Under the Pretext of Brotherly
Love," and appeared in the Viltis (Hope), which is being published in the city
of Vilna (Lithuania). In his article, Dumbre severely censures the Polish
land barons in Lithuania for their plan to invite Polish immigrants to take over
our land; he appears to be very angry at this ungrateful action of the Polish
barons. He probably has a right to expect gratitude from the Polish landowners
in Lithuania, but what right have we to get angry when others try to make use
of something which we have voluntarily discarded? It is foolish
to do so.

No, we must not get angry, but go into action. We must do something to prevent all this work from going to naught. We must
put forth every effort to revive our nationality. But what can
we do? The answer is very short: Let us return to our Fatherland and live there. I am not saying that we should return without money, and
thereby increase the number of the poor in our Fatherland. We should return
with money, purchase the land that is for sale, establish modern farms, and
take commerce and industry into our own hands. There is plenty of land, and
there is no shortage of necessary commodities in the Fatherland; all that is
needed is people with sufficient means to get established. But the greatest
obstacle is a lack of money with which to become established. How can we obtain
money for this purpose?

Ways and means for raising the necessary funds can be found if we care to do so.
We, undoubtedly, still possess a loyal feeling towards our Fatherland. We always
support every good cause for the benefit of our nationality.
If we have made many sacrifices in the past, then how can we
fail to assist in assuring the very life and existence of our
Fatherland in the future? In the long run, that would not be
a sacrifice, but a deed for our own benefit. Those of us who
are here know very well that life in America is not as sweet
as it is being pictured. Those who will return to the Fatherland will only escape all kinds of dangers to their lives and health, many
hardships due to unemployment and strikes, the feeling of insecurity, and the
ghastly fear of the future.

Therefore, while employment lasts, all those who are sympathetic to this movement can group themselves together, and contribute a certain amount of money
every month to a common fund for the purpose of buying land in the Fatherland.
The plan should be operated in a manner that will be satisfactory to all members
of the group; no one should be deceived, nor overburdened. The contributors to
the fund will be made up of two groups: The first group will consist of those
who will take over and live on the purchased land; the second group will aid
the first group. Therefore, not all members of the group can
expect a large financial return for their money, but they will
have the satisfaction of having aided a worthy cause, which is
worth more than money. It is not necessary for all members to
invest an equal sum of money, but only as much as they are able.
Investors in this project cannot expect large dividends, but
their money will be safe; and they will have the satisfaction of
knowing that their money will be aiding the Fatherland.

If the above plan is employed, in would not be difficult to raise the necessary
funds for this important cause; all that is needed is the will to do so.

I have explained these matters in detail to the Lithuanian public, because I
hold them to be of great importance. however, if there are people who disagree
with my views, than I would be very glad to hear from them.
